conclusion: The particle starts from rest (initial velocity v₀ = 0), and the problem involves analyzing acceleration-time and velocity-time graphs to find when the particle is farthest from the starting point.

The acceleration-time graph shows: (1) From t = 0 to t = t₀/2, a = a₀; (2) From t = t₀/2 to t = t₀, a decreases linearly from a₀ to 0; (3) From t = t₀ to t = 3t₀/2, a decreases linearly from 0 to -a₀; (4) From t = 3t₀/2 to t = 2t₀, a increases linearly from -a₀ to 0.
The velocity-time graph shows: (1) Velocity starts at 0; (2) Increases to a maximum value of a₀t₀/2 around t = t₀; (3) Decreases back to 0 at t = 2t₀.
The displacement of the particle equals the area under the velocity-time curve.
To find when the particle is farthest from the starting point, I need to find when the displacement is at its maximum.
Since the velocity is always positive from t = 0 to t = 2t₀ (the curve stays above the t-axis), the displacement continually increases during this time.
The particle will be farthest from the starting point when the velocity becomes zero again, which occurs at t = 2t₀.

From t = 0 to t = 2t₀, the particle is moving in the positive direction (v > 0). At t = 2t₀, the particle stops (v = 0). After this, if the motion were to continue, the particle would start moving back.
The particle is farthest from the starting point at time t = 2t₀, when its velocity returns to zero after moving in the positive direction.
